titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. Ne cede malis, sed contra fortiori ito— Bailey here— Tennessee— Brent and Watkins Claims on Spain for French captures— M. Sterling of New-York. recommends Butterfield— His motion upon claims before Congress— At the President’s— Crowd of Company— Indians there after we came away— Wedding visit at Van Ness’s, to Arthur Middleton— Spoke to Russell, and Eustis— At the Office— Letter to General Jackson— Canning— Affair of the Commissioners, Porter and Barclay— Of S. H. Wilcocke— We had company to dinner—

2. VI:30. At P.U.S: with Letter of 27. December from Anduaga, and my answer— S. Thompson there— Stockton’s capture of a Portuguese vessel— Consequences— Letter from P.U.S. to Genl. Jackson, accepting his resignation— Thompson’s objections.—discussed— My confidential communications to P.U.S— His remarks— Russell— last Administration— Amado at the Office His Letter— P.U.S. sent for his Letter to Jackson, to alter it— Eve at S. Thompson’s— Mrs. A did not go. Talk with R. King and J. W. Taylor, of commercial affairs— With Van Buren about Jackson— Dancing.

3. VI. At the Office—W. Plumer— Conversed this Morning with Calhoun— J. D. Dickenson— I did not see him— Evening party at Van Ness’s— Did not go— Mary Hellen only went— M. L Hill here— Maine Politics— District judge— Presidential Election— W. King— Ware— Ames— Williamson— A. K. Parris—

4. VI:30. Lambert here, about his report on the meridian— Commodore Hull— At the Office Amado— The Portuguese prize of the Alligator— At P.U.S— He sent for Secy. of the Navy— Letter to G. Blake. Note to Secy Navy— Draft to R. Rush— P.U.S. told me of the Post-Office at Albany— Postmaster General— S. Southwick and S. Van Rensselaer. Secy. of the Navy— Vice-President and Van Buren.

5. VI: At the Office— Mallary— Case of S. H. Wilcocke— Read to him Letter from Griswold Case of Commissioners 5. Article Ghent Treaty— Poinsett— Diplomatic papers— Gallatin’s calculations— Note from P.U.S— Cabinet Meeting— Postmaster at Albany. R. J. Meigs, Postmaster General R. J. Meigs came in— Letters from Tompkins, King and Van Buren— discussion— Recommendation from 22 N’York members— Exceptions Pitcher, Litchfield M’Carty and Walworth— Animadversions upon R. J. Meigs— Diversity of opinions— Thompson remained with P.U.S. Letter to R. Rush— Joseph Lancaster came and dined with us— His new project— Mr & Mrs Frye here at Eve— Calhoun & the widow Carter— Changed Chambers— cold. F. 5.

6. V:45. Heard Dr Staughton at the Capitol. 1 Peter 2.21— Example— J. Sergeant. W. King. Visits at Coyle’s—to Holmes of Miss. Rankin &c— Then at Queen’s Hotel to Boardman, M. L. Hill &c— Next at Rapine’s to Gist’s &c— to Mrs Queen jr. to M’Neill, Long &c—and N. Edwards of Illinois— Brown S.U.S. of Louisiana came in talk with Edwards— After visit at Mrs Blake’s to S. Southard
Jas. D. Breckenridge, and Rodney, who is ill— Mrs Clark and Susan here— D. P. Cook in the Evening— His Resolutions— Talk with him.

7. V. Mrs Coulon, Armstrong’s mother here. W King and H. L. White. At the Office; Nelson of Massachusetts— Enquiry for papers relating to claims— S. Thompson—Secy. Navy— About the Slave Ship at Boston— Lieutt. Inman’s Letter— Third Letter from Amado— Sent for him— Told him I had written to Distt. Attorney Boston— At P.U.S. with a Letter of 11 Decr. and final argument from Fromentin— Case of the Postmaster at Albany— P.U.S. will not interfere— Numerous evening party— S. Van Rensselaer appointed—

8. VII:30.Baldwin was here, with Irish—Marshal—Eastern District of Pennsylvania— His papers— State Politics— Genl.Winder— Spanish claim Commission— At the Office. Calls from Jonn. Russell, and Stevenson— Pegram— At P.U.S.— His advice to send all Pegram’s papers. Mrs Hay and child arrived while I was there— Note from Hyde—Apollon— Eve at Calhoun’s.

9. VII. Induction of the Columbian College— Dr Staughton’s Address— Dr Morse went with Johnson Hellen and George— At the Office— Captain Reed of the Navy— At P.U.S. with Hyde’s— Anduaga’s, and Torres’s Notes— His opinions: Drawing-room at P.U.S.— Thin. Eaton.

10. VII:Dr Morse at the Office— His Report upon the Indians— Indian titles— Census. H. Niles. Articles in his paper upon Etiquette— At P.U.S.— To call a Meeting, to-morrow, at Noon— Dined at Mr Canning’s— Diplomatic, reconciliation dinner— Evening at Van Ness’s, deuce with Mrs Middleton— Chess with Coll. Henderson.

11. VII.Noble here. S.U.S.— District Attorney Indiana— Cushman—District judge—Maine. Cabinet Meeting at Noon— Wirt absent— Mexico— Recognition of South-American Governments— Crawford for sending a Minister, to use influence against the erection of monarchical Governments— Calhoun for immediate acknowledgment— Thompson doubts its expediency— No conclusion— Shaler— Crawford’s remark upon him— Call of H.R. upon Calhoun for cessions by Indian Treaties— M. L. Hill— Anduaga’s Notes— Papers partly read— Crawford withdrew— Answer to Anduaga not determined— Torres’s Notes— D. Webster at the Office—did not see him— Frye’s here this Eve. Visit from two Missouri Indians.

12. VII.Jonathan Russell here— Conversation on public affairs—with France—Spain—G. Britain— Jackson and Florida— Personal explanation— Calhoun told M. Morton that Russell’s not being employed abroad, was owing to some personal difference between Russell and me— I told Russell what the President had said—he appeared satisfied— Said he was disposed entirely to harmonize with the Executive— At the Office— Palmer S.U.S. with a petition for a pardon of a man in Vermont. Mitchell for an English Report on Bankrupt Laws. Genl. P. B. Porter— State of the Ghent Treaty Commission Article 6— Baldwin— Report of agreement with British Government not to increase duties on either side. P.U.S.— Vice President and Lowndes’s visit to England—a baseless story— Note from Baldwin— Webster—case of Portuguese vessel at Boston— Canning.
Letter from Barclay— Cession—discussion of Barclay’s proposal— Offer to suspend decision upon the 6th. and begin on 7th. Article— Not allowed by the Treaty—read 7th. Article. Case of Wilcocke—implication of forgery— Case of Hoopla— Letter from Lord Dalhousie—no British subjects concerned in carrying off Hoopla— Reward offered. We had company to dine— Hyde’s Evening party. George, Mrs Clark & Mary Hellen went.

13. VII: Heard at the Capitol, Friend George Withy: rather dull— Visits to Hendricks—sick. J. W. Taylor, and Butler of N.H.— At Mrs Payton’s to White, W. King, Tazewell, &c— Gray there, and left Cards— At Mrs Ball’s to Talbot, W. Taylor, and D. P. Cook— Bayly there— Evening W. King— J. HolmesChandler, and M. L. Hill— District Judge in Maine— They recommend Ware— 13. Ames— Williamson—Whitman— King said he intended to have taken no part in politics. Parris just sent his resignation to Holmes.

14. V: At the Office— Genl. P. B. Porter, with papers— Dr. Morse—Indian titles— Cranch Vol. 6. Parish,— with a Letter from Canning to A: Barclay— Letters from G. Blake and Fromentin— at P.U.S.—Secy of Navy came in— Notes from Torres— Acknowledgment of South-American Independence— Not advisable yet— Mexico— Shaler— Letter to G. Blake— Mrs Clark and Susan left us— Mary, Eve at Mr T. Munroe’s.

15. VII.Lambert here— His Report, printing delayed. F. C. Gray— Recognition of Spanish and South-American Government’s— Wait’s State papers— Onis’s Memoir— Wheatons Appendix Vol. 3. Edwards S.U.S. and judge W. P. Duval— Florida— Grecians— Land-titles— Governor’s White and Coppinger— At the Office— Herrick—District judge in Maine—favours Ames— F. C. Gray— State papers— Hersant with a Note from Hyde— R. King—for Hertsletts Treaties. St. Sebastian cases. Mr. M’Coyabout the pardon of W. Scott. Costs and charges. Sloan and Chambers—about the Marshal of Ohio— Hamm’s construction of the Census act.

16. VI:Williamson here—wishes to be District judge in Maine— Says Parris told him he would take no part in the appointment— King and Holmes coalition— Ware’s youth— At the Office. Newton. Commercial Affairs— Cape of Good Hope. & Mauritius. Menou, from Hyde, about La Pensée, and the Africans— At P.U.S.— Meeting fixed for to-morrow— South American Independence—La Pensée— Clay, running here— Tucker, and Declaration of Independence— Draft to Hyde about La Jeune Eugenie— Sent correspondence with Pegram to Stevenson— Letter to Pegram— To M. L. Hill about Cain— To M’Coy about . . .Scott— Letter from my son John— His Cousin Thomas— Mary Roberdeau here— F. C. Gray, this Evening.

17. V:30. Letters to W. H. Allen, my Son John and brother. Cabinet Meeting at Noon— Recognition of Colombia, Buenos-Ayres, Chili— Message in part prepared—asking for appropriations— Discussion— Crawford earnest, to send Ministers, without waiting first to receive them— Wirt asks what change has taken place? Lima— Carthagena— Cumana taken — Calhoun asks what would be a more proper time? When the war shall have entirely ceased— The only question, as to the effect upon Spain— Crawford says our relations with Spain, are already as bad as they can be— Conclusion— The Message to be sent, this Session— Members to be talked with in the interval.
I am to answer Torres provisionally— Hyde’s Note, claiming La Pensee and her Cargo of Negroes, to be delivered up to him— Has P.U.S. the authority to deliver up— Crawford, Calhoun, Wirt say yes— Thompson hesitates— I have very serious doubts— Reminded Wirt of his opinion, against delivery of criminal fugitives— Crawford says the Cargo of La Pensée, have no Rights—compared to the case of La jeune Eugenie—which Calhoun says is a stronger case to doubt the authority of P.U.S. to deliver up— Hyde’s Letter given to Wirt for a written opinion. He said he was very busy, preparing for the Session of the Supreme Court— I drafted answer to Torres— We had company to dine— Mr & Mrs Frye here— Evening at Mrs Brown of Louisiana’s party—J. H. Eaton—Baldwin &c.

18. VII:30. At the Office— J. A. Hamilton—enquires for files or records of his father’s Reports to President Washington— His claim on Spain— Decision of the Commissioners that claims by contracts are not included in the Treaty. Letter to Governor of Virginia, with Copy of the Census of that Commonwealth— O’Brien—His Letter from James Bratin, at Carlisle— George Bryan to be the next Candidate for Governor of Pennsylvania. Characters of the members of the Pennsylvania delegation— Rogers and four more went to Calhoun— R. J. Meigs of the scheme— Gibson’s brother at Carlisle— Calhoun there last Summer: projected public dinner, failed— Gist— Tucker— Wilson— S. Carolina members offended with Calhoun’s confidences to Dwight, a Massachusetts Federalist. Miss Roberdeau and Mary Hellen, went to Genl. Mason’s— Georgetown.

19. VI: At the Office. J. H. Eaton to recommend Captain Call, as District Attorney, Pensacola. Genl. Jackson, and Fromentin’s Affair— Walker of Alabama— Draft of Joshua Norvell, on Secy. of the Treasury for $500—pretended authority from me—examined my Letters—must have been a forgery— Walker asks copies of my Letters— Rice enquires about claims on Christophe— Cuthbert— Testimonial in favour of Morel— Has two daughters charges in anonymous Letter false— Lowndes— English and French weights and Measures. Committee propose four Resolutions— Homans from Navy Department, with papers relating to the Daphne— Thomas Osgood Whitcomb—and Isaac Hull Adams for warrants of Midshipmen— P. B. Porter, called for his map and papers— Boardman, Tomkinson, and Barber; recommend Andrew Hull junr. as Marshal for Connecticut. Foote’s father in Law— Letters from Dearborn, Degrand, Anonymous, from S.C.— Miss Roberdeau, and Mary Hellen back from Georgetown— Letter from W. N. Boylston.

20. VII. Heard Sparks at the Capitol. Matthew 15.10. Hear and Understand— Visit at Miss Heyer’s—to Warfield. Buchanan and J. Sergeant— R. Wright there: repeated two Hymns of his composition. O’Brien came in— Milnor— Left a Card at M’Leod’s for Condict— at Brown’s Hotel for J. P. Duval. Saw Russ at Hyatt’s— Conkling’s, Lincoln, Ruggles and Tracy at Mrs Tucker’s— Letter from C. Shaler.

21. VII.D. P. Cook here— His Resolutions— Calhoun’s Conversations with him. Rogers’s—high canvassing. At the Office—Stevenson—Application for discharge of the Pirates in prison at Richmond—expensiveness of keeping them—bad keeping—licentiousness, some improperly discharged— the lists— Census papers— He has received them— Barber of Ohio— About the Marshal— His doubts whether Hamm ought to be reappointed or not— E. Wyer— Yesterday arrived from Boston— J. Rhea here this Eve—young party and dance.

22. VI: MrBrowne of Ohio, S.U.S. and Vance of H.R. here. About the appointment of a Marshal in Ohio— The whole delegation have given up Hamm— Miner, Dougherty and Whittlesea recommended— At the Office— De Menou— With Translations of Hydes last two Notes— Genl. P. B. Porter— Letter from A. Barclay: to meet him at Philadelphia the 29th. Porter’s apprehension that Barclay will break off— Asks advice whether he shall accept his line?— At P.U.S.— Case of La Pensèe— Wirt’s opinion not yet given— Various questions; Porter’s enquiry— Administration Meeting to-morrow: He to be present— Floyd’s Resolution. Its object.

23. VI:30. Change of Weather in the Night, from 41 to 23. New Moon— At the Office. P. B. Porter. Meeting at P.U.S. to-morrow— Buck— demand in favour of Hamburg vessels—our demand against the 10 per Cent jus detractus— Letters to Leamy, C. S. Todd, Buck, Speaker H.R. and J. H. Jackson— Wirt’s opinion in the case of La Pensée— Pirates, Robbers, Assassins, Traitors, are entitled to National Hospitality; but Negroes “have no rights”—So says Crawford— Negroes are “Cargo”— And as Cargo of a Ship, the President has power to deliver them up at the demand of a foreign Minister. So Says Wirt Biographer of Patrick Henry.— At home found James Johnson, who dined with us and went with me to the drawing Room— Miss Roberdeau gone— Talk with Baldwin—manufacturers discontented— Archer— West-India trade— Marriott’s Letter— Gallatin and Castlereagh— R. King— Maine boundary— Negotiation rather than reference— Spoke to P.U.S.— Meeting to-morrow— Home with James Johnson to Georgetown— Frye’s this Evening here.

24. V:30. At the Office— Tod of H.R. from Pennsylvania— Resolution of Legislature for certified aggregate Census to put on their Journals— Cabinet Meeting—full. Genl. P. B. Porter present— Barclay’s proposal— Middle of rivers— Channels— Cubic volume of water— Barclay’s offer not acceptable— Case of La Pensée— Wirt’s opinion— Salvage— Power of P.U.S.— Laws of Louisiana— What would I do? What would humanity require? Hyde will take them only with their own consent— Question still undecided. Wirt wishes for more information. Case of La Jeune Eugénie not parallel. We had company to dine— Florida Treaty Commissioners &c— Met Hay this Morning— Contract Claims. Lent him my Report to P.U.S. on Meade’s Memorial— Letter from E. Everett, with enclosure from A. H. Everett, to Jos. Hall— Letter to President Kirkland, and W. N. Boylston— S. Smith at the Office— Complaint against Calhoun—

25. V:30. Called up to George who was ill all Night. Sent for Dr Huntt— D. P. Cook here, with West from Illinois— At the Office— J. A. Hamilton; Letter from him about contract claims—Answer— He goes for New-York to-morrow— Coll. R. M. Johnson, about C. S. Todd’s accounts—when he may go— Johnson recommends Prentiss, who, he says has ruined him— Shaler—about the Governor of St. Bartholomews, Norderling— And wishes Conversation with me on Barbary concerns, another day— Tooker, to recommend Hubble as Consul at Manilla— Asks if Captain Henley has not testified against Stewart? No. Wyer—loose talk—Orne—about Jos. D. Howe’s claim—advised him to speak to the Secretary of the Navy— Richardson from Cincinnati, with R. M. Johnson who withdrew— Kentucky and Ohio Politicks— George kept his Chamber. Fahrenheit 5.

26. VII:Burton here—requests me to write again to Broadbent, Consul at Messina— Russell— Trimble’s Call for Papers— Louisiana Convention claim— Should those papers be communicated to Congress? Majority of Committee, think the claim founded— Ghent Treaty papers— Russell’s Letter of 25. Decr. 1814. Left to himself whether it shall be sent in or withheld— He thought it a private Letter— His remark on the observation of P.U.S. concerning himself— At the Office— Upham—application for pardon of James Chase— P. B. Porter, going to-morrow for Philadelphia, to meet Barclay— R. King and Van Buren—copies of Secret Journals of Congress— Expenditures for Seamen— Eustis— Extravagance of War Department— Claims of Scott and Gaines— Letter from Mr Eustis— J. G. Forbes— At P.U.S. — Answer to Hamilton—to have an Administrative Meeting— G. Hay—late dinner.

27. VII. Snow, then hail and Sleet—then rain— The Streets a glare of ice— Set out for Church at Georgetown—but was obliged to come back— Horses not roughshod. Went to the Bath-room— No preaching there— Visits to E. A. Brown, Senator from Ohio— To West—to S. Southwick, late Postmaster at Albany, to G. Tucker, and E. B. Jones at Mrs Wilson’s— Letter from C. Raguet to J. Sergeant— from Degrand— George still keeps chamber.

28. VII.B. O. Tyler here, for music— S. Southwick’s hard case— D. W. Clinton owes him 6000 dollars, lent him to promote his advancement— Cushman came with a Patent letter— Opposition to A. Ware, as District Judge in Maine— Duval Judge in East Florida—to enquire what his Salary will be— Talk of Kentucky Politicks— Hardin, Pope, Trimble, Clay— Pope he thinks will come to the next Congress— Bailey here with Childs— At the Office— Then at P.U.S. Met Wirt there— Ware’s appointment— President’s impressions— Florida papers sent to H.R. with a Message— Meeting for to-morrow at one— About the Answer to Hamilton— George still confined— Mary Hellen unwell—

29. VII:Bailey here. Letter to D’Wolfe from the Havanna—to be published or communicated— At the Office— Shaler— Mexican pamphlet— Barbary— Instructions to naval
Commanders to consult with him— Presents to be withheld— Norderling— Buck. Claim for Hamburg vessels again— Cabinet Meeting at P.U.S. opinion of Commissioners, on contract claims— Hamilton’s Letter— Not to be answered— Thompson’s opinion that contract claims were not included— The record examined— Right of a Government to renounce contract claims—or claims for torts— Answer to Call of H.R. upon Havanna outrages— George and Mary Hellen confined.

30. VII.D. P. Cook here— Act of 22. Geo: 3. ch. 45. Debates in Parliament— Govr Branch of N.C. to be Governor of Floridas— W. P. Duval. Coll. Troup. Question of influence. At the Office— Answer to Hyde, on the Apollon— Reading papers— Letter to my Son John— George and Mary Hellen still keep chamber.

31. VI:Newton here— Enquiry for papers— State of our Commerce with Spain, Portugal, and the rest of Europe— Mauritius and Cape of Good Hope— Note from P.U.S. nominations. Gouverneur here— A. Ware to be District judge in Maine— Nomination delayed till tomorrow— At the Office— Josiah Meigs— Green’s copy-right— Attorney General’s opinion— Will W. S. Smith stay at Pensacola? Buck— Hamburg and discriminating duties—what can be done? E. Wyer—The same— Captain Reed—a visit— At P.U.S.—found Lacock with him—he withdrew. I asked P.U.S. to delay Ware’s nomination— He objects that he may be thought to be influenced by Judge Story—but promises delay— Shewed me a recommendation of Ware by Holmes, Chandler, W. King,Hill and Lincoln, announcing Ware, as the only man who will be acceptable to the people of Maine— Says they told him Williamson was a man of no consideration, and would not be re-elected—that Ames in the late War went into the British Provinces for refuge. That Ware was part owner, and a writer, for a newspaper from Patriotism— That Ames had been a double dealer—promising to support the State Administration on one side, and the federalists on the other—and that the State Printer had been charged by an intrigue of Ames, in appointing a Committee— I left with him the papers relating to the appointment of a District Attorney in Indiana— The two Senators and Hendricks recommend Sullivan— The Governor and District Judge C. Dewey who has been appointed— I objected to the Constitutionality of pre-nominations by Senators— He said he should nominate Dewey— And that the recommendation of the Maine Senators, for which they had apologised was a private paper, which he should not deposit in the Department of State— He gave me the Albany Memorial against the Postmaster General, and Documents— Said he did not suppose the memorial would require an answer— South-American Affairs— Nelson’s call for papers. intended message— We had Company to dinner— Congress-men— Calhoun— Evening at Kerr’s party— Otis’s account of Vice-President Tompkins’s tumble, this day at the Senate— An overflow of Spirits— Dickinson’s remarks on the Albany Memorial— Not 60 people at the Meeting— Members of the Legislature would not attend— The recanting members here, ashamed of their recantation— Tompkins not a reasonable man— Van-Buren the factotum— Trimble’s motion made for recognition of South-American Independence—
